quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The company has a tendency to over-invest. Startups have the benefit of starving, and so you need to create scarcity.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A contrarian mental model for 0→1 inside big companies: intentionally constrain resources to mimic startup urgency and focus.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What we try to do is remind everyone things are going to fail, let's not drag the rest of the company into it.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Practical guidance on limiting blast radius—set expectations of failure and isolate early bets from the broader org.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I needed the rest of the company to go away so we could get the autonomy to test the things that we needed, but it's not going to scale. That is not going to respect all design guidelines.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A framework for incubation: prioritize autonomy and rapid testing over scalability and strict compliance early on.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Be very clear about what we're testing, doing that with data, doing that with personal customer stories, give people a sense of velocity and speed. No one wants to fuck with a high-speed train.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A playbook for protecting fragile early products: define explicit tests, back them with evidence, and demonstrate momentum to deter premature shutdowns.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: My track record at Atlassian has been 50/50 at best.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A concrete data point that normalizes failure rates in internal innovation and sets realistic expectations for 0→1 bets.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta's market leading trust management platform helps you continuously monitor compliance alongside reporting and tracking risks.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: Highlights an operational approach to compliance: continuous monitoring paired with risk reporting/tracking rather than point-in-time audits.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: Actionable efficiency claim: using AI to reduce time spent on repetitive security questionnaire work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A practical product planning heuristic: enterprise readiness becomes a customer-driven requirement as you scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: A scalable authorization mental model: optimize for both performance at scale and flexibility for complex permissioning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Concrete adoption data point/value proposition that can influence build-vs-buy decisions for auth/enterprise features.

quotes.topic_title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
quotes.text: The thing inside Atlassian is that the path for success is super high for a new bet.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Highlights a core 0-to-1 failure mode in big companies: early bets are held to an unusually high bar from day one.

quotes.topic_title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
quotes.text: A $100 million business is a good start basically. In most companies out there, $100 million business is a home run. For us, it's not like that.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A concrete example of how “success” thresholds in large companies can distort decision-making for new products.

quotes.topic_title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
quotes.text: Now, evaluating success can look very different between early stage and established products.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Sets up the key methodology shift required for incubation: different stages need different evaluation criteria.

quotes.topic_title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
quotes.text: For a long time at Atlassian, we were treating everything a little bit equally in that the metrics success for the same. For example, things like monthly active users is the way that you, for a long time we looked at you go, is that product being successful on it?
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Actionable warning against applying mature-product metrics (like MAUs) to early-stage bets.

quotes.topic_title: Why 0-to-1 is hard in big companies
quotes.text: They're going to try it and then they're going to churn and it's going to take forever to claim them back, so that makes it pretty challenging to try and start new things unless we've got the right metrics and processes and everything internally that can give room and breathing space for the bets to succeed internally.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Explains the compounding cost of premature scaling and why incubators/“breathing room” mechanisms matter.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
quotes.text: We tried to grow it very aggressively for a product that did not change that fast before it had reached good product market fit already, hundreds of thousands of users on a daily basis, and all of a sudden that you get a lot of people who want to make changes to it, to compete against this new threat.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A cautionary lesson about scaling teams and change velocity post-PMF—adding lots of people and changes quickly can destabilize a mature product when reacting to a fast-moving competitor.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
quotes.text: The platform is not so ready for so many people to work on it.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Highlights an often-missed scaling constraint: internal developer throughput and architecture can become the bottleneck when headcount ramps.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
quotes.text: There's lots of literature around there around should you do rewrite? Should you not do rewrite? You ask me now, I tell you never. Trust me.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A blunt, experience-backed stance against rewrites—useful as a default heuristic when teams feel forced into “start over” decisions under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
quotes.text: Because that was what helped us, how we thought we would win, and it was how I think we lost.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that perceived strategic advantages (like bundling/distribution) can backfire and become the mechanism of failure.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat story: scaling up and rewriting
quotes.text: as soon as we did that, our stock price went up. I think it was $60 back then and it went up to 70. I mean, that really sucked for us, the team working on it.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how markets can reward shutting down a product even when it’s emotionally devastating for the team—useful for understanding incentives and stakeholder perspectives.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
quotes.text: The founders keep telling us what took us here won't take us there.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why past success doesn’t automatically translate to new products or segments.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
quotes.text: The thing is we didn't, in my opinion, do enough to validate that assumption early enough.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A direct warning to test key go-to-market and adoption assumptions early, before investing heavily.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
quotes.text: Emojis, a lot of other things that may at some point I remember we were thinking those things were trivial. No, they were not trivial.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that “small” UX/social features can be decisive for different user segments.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
quotes.text: Don't just go and build on those assumptions.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Actionable product-development advice: validate hypotheses instead of treating them as facts.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: validate assumptions early
quotes.text: And that's when we saw, I think it was in two weeks, we got more than 3000 signups to that waitlist.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A concrete validation tactic and data point: run a waitlist/CTA before writing code to test reach and demand.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
quotes.text: The first one is competitive myopia, don't fall for it.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A crisp warning against letting competitor moves dictate your roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
quotes.text: your competitor, if you think of what they do as an iceberg, the top side, what comes out of the water is what they've shipped in terms of features, but it's based on all this stuff that they've built in terms of research and understanding of their customer base and everything else.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why copying shipped features is misleading without the underlying customer insight.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
quotes.text: we often have discussions to go back, to okay, let's watch again the user interviews that we did over the past three weeks. Let's watch them all together now and remember who we are building this for.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A practical team ritual for re-anchoring decisions on customer evidence when competitor news creates distraction.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
quotes.text: Where it's really difficult is when you try to do the two at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive caution that rebuilding and platformizing simultaneously can slow learning and execution.

quotes.topic_title: HipChat lessons: competition myopia and scarcity
quotes.text: we need to win the problem space first, and if the platform is there, let's use it. If it's not there, we'll hack it, test it, iterate on it with customers, and then whatever is good there, let's platformize it later.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A sequencing methodology: validate customer problems fast first, then invest in platformization after proof.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
quotes.text: That's more like a story of big companies can play the long run and for you individually inside that process, it might look like a loss and you might feel like you're going nowhere, yet the company stays on the opportunity for long enough to make it happen.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A mental model for interpreting “failure” inside large orgs: individual timelines can mislead even when the company is making a correct long-term bet.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
quotes.text: And when I was watching teams in incidents, I realized that there's a lot of chicken without a head syndrome, headless chicken, people running around like bunch of headless chicken.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A vivid diagnosis of incident response dysfunction that practitioners can use to recognize when coordination—not tooling depth—is the primary bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
quotes.text: What Statuspage was offering is something seemingly super simple, which is, well, what you should have is a status page for your services and you tell your customers about it and you can subscribe to your status page.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Highlights a “simple surface area, big leverage” product pattern: a lightweight artifact (status page) can unlock outsized operational and customer outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
quotes.text: it's going to build trust with them because basically you are open in your communication with them. They're more likely to empathize with your position and be supportive as opposed to, "Oh, that stuff is done again."
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive customer-ops insight: transparency during outages can increase trust and reduce backlash rather than amplify it.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage: incident communication and market context
quotes.text: Now, big companies like Atlassian, we've got money. So in every strategy that we've got, we've got cash in the bank, we always look at should we build, should we buy, should we partner?
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A practical strategic framework for scaling into new markets: explicitly evaluate build vs. buy vs. partner as a standard decision lens.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
quotes.text: So big company, we've got cash, we can buy a company, it will make us go faster, is not always the case.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that acquisitions don’t automatically accelerate execution, even when the buyer has resources.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
quotes.text: So that is the things that people told me when I started working on the integration, which is, hey, remember, you don't know yet, but integrations are mostly about people. They're not about technology as much or product vision. All of that stuff is the easy stuff. The hard part is the people.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A clear mental model for post-acquisition integration: people/process challenges dominate over tech and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
quotes.text: Because what we tell those companies is we can accelerate by buying, but in reality they are going to be faced with more internal processes around how they manage staff, performance reviews, this concept of engineering allocation, revenue forecasts, OKRs, long-term roadmaps, all that stuff comes in very new to them.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Actionable checklist of the process overhead that commonly slows acquired startups inside larger orgs.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
quotes.text: And it's the things that you used to be able to focus 90% of your time working on your product, and all of a sudden all of that stuff may seem parasitical but comes in and interrupts you all the time.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of the attention-tax that hits teams post-acquisition and why velocity often drops first.

quotes.topic_title: Statuspage integration: acquisitions are about people
quotes.text: So one warning, if you're planning to do acquisitions, make sure you factor all of that in and think about the integration plans to compensate for these aspects. So you don't expect the business to join and keep running at exactly the same pace, because going to be a big slowdown before it accelerates again.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Practical advice to plan for an expected slowdown during integration and design mitigation into the integration plan.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition strategy: frankenstack vs acqui-hire
quotes.text: And so we call that the frankenstack, otherwise. Which is, you get one tech stack here, one tech stack there and they can't quite talk to each other, identity is different, integrating is different. And so it looks like a patchwork of products and that's not what our customers want from us.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Defines the “frankenstack” failure mode and why integration/identity coherence matters to customers post-acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition strategy: frankenstack vs acqui-hire
quotes.text: So the next time I try personally, I would treat it like hiring over treating it like buying business only.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: A practical acquisition lens: optimize for bringing in a capable team (and their know-how), not just the existing product/business.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition strategy: frankenstack vs acqui-hire
quotes.text: Find a company that has amazing product that we can bring in as a tech-in, shut down the product, rebuild it on our platform and so it's basically the equivalent of an acqui-hire, because basically what we'll be buying is the acceleration of our roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Outlines an actionable acquisition playbook: buy small, shut down the product, rebuild on-platform to accelerate roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Acquisition strategy: frankenstack vs acqui-hire
quotes.text: So it's not the same as trying to rebuild the plane mid flight, it's delaying takeoff. It's like, "Yeah, we did a trial run, the plane landed. Okay, cool. Switch to another plane, takeoff again."
quotes.speaker: Tanguy Crusson
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for when rebuilding is viable: avoid rewrites for scaled products with live customer expectations; rebuild only when you can “delay takeoff.”
